items.title: The order is well kept, but the comments are all gone
items.body: Could you make it an option to turn on/off the removal of the comments in the yaml file?

items.title: Yaml file not loaded as OrderedDict
items.body:
The following code gives me a `dict`:

```
import oyaml as yaml
cfg = yaml.load("---\ncat: 1\ndog:\n\tdog1: 2\n\tdog2: 3")
type(cfg)
```

With these module versions:
oyaml                     0.9                      py37_0    conda-forge
pyyaml                    5.1.1            py37h516909a_0    conda-forge
yaml                      0.1.7             h14c3975_1001    conda-forge

items.title: Error reporting is limited when dict key is unhashable
items.body:
If you attempt to parse code that contains a mapping with an unhashable key, yaml raises a ConstructorError that tells the user exactly where the issue was. However, oyaml raises a TypeError, which may be missed by exception handling code expecting a ConstructorError, and which contains no information about where the problem occurred.

```
>>> def test():
...   try:
...     yaml.safe_load("{foo: bar}: baz")
...   except Exception as e:
...     print("%s: %s" % (type(e).__name__, e))
... 
>>> import yaml
>>> test()
ConstructorError: while constructing a mapping
found unacceptable key (unhashable type: 'dict')
  in "<string>", line 1, column 1:
    {foo: bar}: baz
    ^
>>> import oyaml
>>> test()
TypeError: unhashable type: 'OrderedDict'
```

items.title: Can't use both yaml and oyaml at the same time
items.body:
If I import oyaml and yaml at the same time, using yaml lib returns orderedDicts!

Example here. First I open an interactive shell and import yaml, use it to load a file. It returns a dict as expected. Then I import oyaml and run the SAME code as above, using YAML not oyaml and it returns an ordered dict!

In my script, simply writing `import oyaml` at the top, changes the functionality of every `yaml.load` command in the script!

How can I cause these 2 libs to not clash?


```
>>> import yaml
>>> with open('config/config.yaml') as f:
...   config_yaml = yaml.safe_load(f)
... 
>>> config_yaml
{'train': {'datasets': [{'images': ..............


>>> import oyaml
>>> with open('config/config.yaml') as f:
...   config_yaml = yaml.safe_load(f)
... 
>>> config_yaml
OrderedDict([('train', OrderedDict([('datasets', [OrderedDict([('images', ...........
```

items.title: Include license file in source distribution
items.body:
Could the license file be included in the source distribution? See:

https://docs.python.org/2/distutils/sourcedist.html#the-manifest-in-template

items.title: Problem dumping nested yaml
items.body:
I'm seeing an issue when dumping nested YAML where any items printed from sub-dictionaries are surrounded with brackets. Consider the following example:

```
from collections import OrderedDict
from pprint import pprint
import oyaml as yaml

def test():

    myym = """key1: value1
key2: value2
key3:
  - key3a: value3a
  - key3b: value3b
  - key3c:
    - key3c888: value3c888
    - key3c999: value3c999
"""
    
    y = yaml.load(myym)
    print(y)
    print(yaml.dump(y))

if __name__=="__main__":
    test()

```

The output contains `{}` around each sub-key:

```
$ python yaml_test.py
OrderedDict([('key1', 'value1'), ('key2', 'value2'), ('key3', [OrderedDict([('key3a', 'value3a')]), OrderedDict([('key3b', 'value3b')]), OrderedDict([('key3c', [OrderedDict([('key3c888', 'value3c888')]), OrderedDict([('key3c999', 'value3c999')])])])])])
key1: value1
key2: value2
key3:
- {key3a: value3a}
- {key3b: value3b}
- key3c:
  - {key3c888: value3c888}
  - {key3c999: value3c999}
```

items.title: Support !!omap ?
items.body:
```# Explicitly typed ordered map (dictionary).
Bestiary: !!omap
  - aardvark: African pig-like ant eater. Ugly.
  - anteater: South-American ant eater. Two species.
  - anaconda: South-American constrictor snake. Scaly.
  # Etc.
# Flow style
Numbers: !!omap [ one: 1, two: 2, three : 3 ]
```

spec here http://yaml.org/type/omap.html 
pyyaml currently loads these to a list of pairs (tuples)
consider loading into a proper mapping type by default

items.title: can't safely dump OrderedDict
items.body:
```python
$ python
Python 3.6.5 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, Mar 29 2018, 13:14:23) 
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from oyaml import safe_dump
>>> from collections import OrderedDict
>>> safe_dump(OrderedDict([('x', 1), ('y', 2)])
... )
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "lib/python3.6/site-packages/yaml/__init__.py", line 216, in safe_dump
    return dump_all([data], stream, Dumper=SafeDumper, **kwds)
  File "lib/python3.6/site-packages/yaml/__init__.py", line 188, in dump_all
    dumper.represent(data)
  File lib/python3.6/site-packages/yaml/representer.py", line 26, in represent
    node = self.represent_data(data)
  File "lib/python3.6/site-packages/yaml/representer.py", line 57, in represent_data
    node = self.yaml_representers[None](self, data)
  File "lib/python3.6/site-packages/yaml/representer.py", line 229, in represent_undefined
    raise RepresenterError("cannot represent an object: %s" % data)
yaml.representer.RepresenterError: cannot represent an object: OrderedDict([('x', 1), ('y', 2)])
```

items.title: Not working with anchors and references :-(
items.body:
Hi,

I've just tried to use `oyaml` in a project as it's just what I need, but I've run into a problem loading my yaml config file which makes use of anchors and references.

I get error `yaml.constructor.ConstructorError: could not determine a constructor for the tag 'tag:yaml.org,2002:merge'` the first time a reference is encountered.

A complete example with a simple test file...

```
$ cat foo.yml
defaults:
  all: &all
    product: foo
  development: &development
    <<: *all
    profile: bar

development:
  platform:
    <<: *development
    host: baz

$ python3
Python 3.5.2 (default, Oct 18 2016, 11:56:15)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 7.0.2 (clang-700.1.81)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import oyaml as yaml
>>> yaml.load(open('foo.yml', 'r'))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/__init__.py", line 72, in load
    return loader.get_single_data()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 37, in get_single_data
    return self.construct_document(node)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 41, in construct_document
    data = self.construct_object(node)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 86, in construct_object
    data = constructor(self, node)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/oyaml-0.1-py3.5.egg/oyaml.py", line 15, in _constructor
    return OrderedDict(loader.construct_pairs(node))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 141, in construct_pairs
    value = self.construct_object(value_node, deep=deep)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 86, in construct_object
    data = constructor(self, node)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/oyaml-0.1-py3.5.egg/oyaml.py", line 15, in _constructor
    return OrderedDict(loader.construct_pairs(node))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 141, in construct_pairs
    value = self.construct_object(value_node, deep=deep)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 86, in construct_object
    data = constructor(self, node)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/oyaml-0.1-py3.5.egg/oyaml.py", line 15, in _constructor
    return OrderedDict(loader.construct_pairs(node))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 140, in construct_pairs
    key = self.construct_object(key_node, deep=deep)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 86, in construct_object
    data = constructor(self, node)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 414, in construct_undefined
    node.start_mark)
yaml.constructor.ConstructorError: could not determine a constructor for the tag 'tag:yaml.org,2002:merge'
  in "foo.yml", line 5, column 5
>>>
```

BTW, I'm using yaml version 3.12
